description.standard:
Selling 5,000+ copies of a debut novel in 18 months (without a massive social media following) might seem out of reach to most aspiring authors. But, in fact, it‚Äôs not. And our incredible podcast guest, Jennifer Lauer, is here to show you how it's done.

When we last spoke, Jennifer was on the brink of launching her debut sci-fi novel, The Girl in the Zoo. Fast-forward to today, and she's sold over 5,000 copies, launched a successful fiction podcast, and released a new paranormal mystery novella series.

In the episode, you‚Äôll hear us talk about things like:
[05:01] Jennifer's honest breakdown of book launch setbacks, including how she handled unexpected Amazon delays and a COVID diagnosis[07:49] How Jennifer leveraged NetGalley to rack up over 200 Amazon reviews and 250 Goodreads reviews‚Äîand why she says it was worth braving the potential for harsh feedback[10:57] Jennifer's persistence in securing BookBub features for international and US markets that drove her novel to #1 on multiple Amazon lists[21:48] How Jennifer sold just over 5,000 copies in 18 months with minimal social media presence (plus, the importance of releasing your work, even if it's imperfect, and how this mindset contributed to her success)[28:03] How Jennifer's fiction podcast, The Strange Chronicles, helped her overcome writer's block and draft her latest novella in one summer[38:24] The marketing plans for Jennifer's new series launch, including which strategies she's keeping, which she's ditching, and why influencer boxes might not be worth the hypeWhether you're gearing up to launch your first novel or looking to breathe new life into your backlist, this episode is packed with actionable strategies you can use today.

description.standard:
Join us as we uncover what drove change within the Mormon Church, from government pressure on BYU to admit more black students to the church‚Äôs troubling response. We‚Äôll dive into shocking letters sent to black prospective students, a five-step plan to keep them out, and the protests that followed. Learn how government intervention eventually forced the end of discrimination and explore why Mormon leaders were so uneasy with black students. This episode, featuring historian Dr. Matthew Harris, is part of our series on his book¬†Second Class Saints: Black Mormons and the Struggle for Racial Equality.


We are thrilled to announce that we have reached our donation goal to compensate Dr. Matt Harris for his contributions to this series. We sincerely thank everyone who supported this effort. While the goal to pay Matt has been met, producing this series incurred significant costs for the Open Stories Foundation. If you find value in this content and want to help cover these expenses and support future productions, we encourage you to donate at https://www.mormonstories.org/donate/ Your generosity makes a difference‚Äîthank you!

description.standard:
Narrated by Julia White (Cal Poly English, '26) 

Full text of the novel: https://ia903104.us.archive.org/34/items/woolf_aroom/woolf_aroom.pdf

About Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) 
Virginia Woolf was Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was an English writer known for her modernist classics and pivotal feminist works. Her writing experiments with prose and often explores dreamstates, nonlinear narratives, and unconventional perspectives. She was truly an innovator on both stylistic and cultural levels. Her most acclaimed works include Mrs. Dalloway, To the Lighthouse, Orlando, and A Room of One‚Äôs Own.

Synopsis 
A Room of One‚Äôs Own follows Woolf's semi-fictional pursuit to research the topic of Women and Fiction. Woolf walks the audience through her own discoveries and frustrations, particularly highlighting the patriarchal hindrances on women to freely create art.

Chapter Guide 
Ch 1. The narrator (a fictionalized Woolf) is asked to speak on the topic of Women and Fiction and attempts to begin her research at the fictional University of Oxbridge, but is met with obstructions on the basis of her sex. She then attends a university luncheon.
Ch 2. (40:51) The narrator begins her research at the British Museum, and finds that although many books are written by men about women, none of the men seem to align on their opinions of them.
Ch 3. (1:11:45) The narrator finds there is little information on the lives of women in history, and constructs an unfortunate tale regarding Shakespeare‚Äôs fictional sister, Judith.
Ch 4. (1:42:07) She goes on to research the lives of prominent female novelists, and asserts that women‚Äôs circumstances and writing styles differ from men entirely, and are
therefore difficult to compare. 
Ch 5. (2:23:16) The narrator studies the fictional Mary Carmichael‚Äôs novel "Life‚Äôs Adventure" and dissects the types of relationships between fictional female characters.
Ch 6. (2:53:32) The narrator stresses the importance of an androgynous mind in creative expression. She ends by reaffirming the need of women to have their own money and own space, and encourages them to write and be heard.

French Translations 
(49:30) ‚ÄúLes femmes sont extr√™mes; elles sont meilleures ou pires que les hommes" : Women are extreme; they are better or worse than men.

Substitutions Made for Date and/or Offensive Language 
(54:19) ‚ÄúPerson‚Äù
(1:29:38) ‚ÄúBlack woman"

Talking Literature presents free audio and text material designed to make literature more accessible for everyone. Each episode of the podcast features important literary texts that are often included in literary surveys and seminars. 

Season 1 features podcasts created during the 23-24 Academic Year and includes works by James Joyce, Kate Chopin, and Henry James.

This podcast reflects Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo's Learn by Doing approach to education and undergraduate research. It began as a Cal Poly English senior project. This podcast has been generously supported by a 2024 Cal Poly College of Liberal Arts Summer Undergraduate Research Program Grant. The inspiration for this podcast was the Library of Congress‚Äô program ‚ÄúTalking Books and Reading Disabilities" (https://www.loc.gov/nls/services-and-resources/informational-publications/talking-books-reading-disabilities/).

description.standard:
Hillsdale College was founded in 1844 with a mission to provide all persons who wish to learn the education necessary to preserve the ‚Äúblessings of civil and religious liberty‚Äù in America. The founders of Hillsdale College understood, like the founders of our great nation, that free government requires independent, virtuous, and knowledgeable citizens.

The Hillsdale College Podcast Network (HCPN) exists to support Hillsdale‚Äôs mission, offering nationwide access to Hillsdale‚Äôs audio content. The HCPN helps radiate the learning, teaching, and discussions that happen here on campus to people everywhere. Supported by you, our listeners, we seek to invite you into the conversation about ‚Äúthe best that has been thought and said.‚Äù

The HCPN includes five shows: The Larry P. Arnn Show, Hillsdale Dialogues, The Radio Free Hillsdale Hour, Beyond the Bubble, and the Hillsdale College K-12 Classical Education Podcast, with additional shows being planned for launch in the coming year.

description.short: This episode addresses the elephant slouching on its phone in the corner of many literature classrooms. Mary Isbell (University of New Haven) describes her search for a solution to the student reading crisis, incorporating conversations recorded as she
description.standard: This episode addresses the elephant slouching on its phone in the corner of many literature classrooms. Mary Isbell (University of New Haven) describes her search for a solution to the student reading crisis, incorporating conversations recorded as she was writing Searching for Wonder: Teaching Literature with Student-Selected Texts. These conversations reveal the many reasons faculty may be hesitant to set aside their carefully curated reading lists. With her guests, Isbell explores the history of literature instruction, the firm hold of close reading on the teaching of literature, the role of scholarly expertise in the humanities classroom, and the challenge of assessing process in literature courses. Production support by Stefan Sch√∂berlein (Texas A&M University-Central Texas). Transcript available at bit.ly/S0902Transcript. To read the conclusion of Isbell's book Searching For Wonder, visit bit.ly/S09E02Resources.

attributes.name: S09 E02 | How Do We Teach Literature When Students Won‚Äôt Read What We Assign?

description.standard:
Narrated by Julia White (Cal Poly English, '26)

Full text of the novel: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/208/pg208-images.html

About Henry James (1843-1916)
Henry James was an American-British author acclaimed for his critical novels on the differences between his two cultures. He was born in Washington Place, New York and spent much of his childhood in Paris, London, and Geneva. James‚Äôs specialty was prose fiction, yet he found work in journalism as well; he produced 20 novels, 112 tales, and 12 plays. James wrote Daisy Miller in 1879 after settling in London. 

Major Characters 
Frederick Winterbourne: Primary character. Young American man who has spent much of his life in Geneva. 
Daisy Miller: A vacationing young American woman known for her flirtation. 
Mrs. Miller: Daisy‚Äôs subdued mother. 
Randolph Miller: Daisy‚Äôs nine-year-old brother. Prefers America over Europe.  
Mrs. Costello: Winterbourne‚Äôs aunt he stays with in Vevey and Rome. Disapproves of the Miller Family‚Äôs manners. 
Eugenio: The Miller‚Äôs courier.  
Mr. Giovanelli: Daisy‚Äôs Roman courter. 
Mrs. Walker: A friend of Winterbourne and the Miller Family‚Äôs host in Rome.  

Synopsis 
Operating in third-person limited perspective, Daisy Miller is a novel of manners that follows ex-patriot Frederick Winterbourne‚Äôs attraction and curiosity of Daisy Miller, a coquette (woman who trifles with men‚Äôs affections) American girl scolded for her behavior in urbane European society. 

Chapter Guide 
Ch 1. Winterbourne and Daisy meet in Vivey. He finds her beautiful and flirtatious. The two make plans to spend a day at the Castle of Chillon.  
Ch 2. (24:03) Winterbourne finds Mrs. Costello does not approve of the Miller family. Winterbourne speaks in the garden of their hotel to Daisy and Mrs. Miller and attempts to 	go on a late-night boat ride with Daisy. The pair later go to the Castle of Chillon by boat on an afternoon tour. Daisy asks Winterbourne to meet her in Rome in winter.
Ch 3. (56:00) Winter. David meets Mrs. Costello in Rome, and she informs him she remains in disapproval of the Miller family. He goes to meet a friend, Mrs. Walker, and 		runs into the Millers. He accompanies Daisy on a stroll with Mr. Giovanelli.
Ch 4. (1:26) Winterbourne sees Daisy and Mr. Giovanelli at Mrs. Walker‚Äôs party, then on a stroll, and finally at the Colosseum. 

French Translations 
(27:57:00) ‚ÄúTout bonnement!‚Äù : Quite simply! 
(1:28:30) ‚ÄúElle s‚Äôaffiche‚Äù : It‚Äôs on display. 
(1:41:25) ‚Äú...and thinks Miss Miller a young lady qui se passe ses fantaisies!‚Äù : and thinks Miss Miller a young lady who indulges her fantasies. 
(1:43:48) ‚Äú...a young lady du meilleur monde‚Äù : a young lady of the best world.

description.standard:
Listen to this audiobook in full for free onhttps://hotaudiobook.com/free Title: To Read Stuff You Have to Know Stuff: Helping Students Build and Use Prior Knowledge¬†Author: Kelly GallagherNarrator: Kelly GallagherFormat: UnabridgedLength: 6:02:14Language: EnglishRelease date: 07-08-2025Publisher: Blackstone AudiobooksGenres: Non-Fiction, EducationSummary:In the age of click-and-go reading, why do students need to know information when they can just look things up?
Bestselling author Kelly Gallagher argues that to think critically, it‚Äôs imperative that we teach kids stuff. Lots of it. Why? Because students who know more are able to read more, and read better.
In To Read Stuff You Have to Know Stuff, Kelly draws from his own teaching practice to share the importance of building students‚Äô prior knowledge at four levels:
Words: How building knowledge helps students to overcome word poverty
Sentences and Passages: How building knowledge helps students to comprehend ‚Äúsmall‚Äù reading
Articles: How building knowledge helps students to critically read articles‚Äïan important skill in our digital age
Books: How building knowledge moves students away from fake reading and back into reading full-length books 
To Read Stuff You Have to Know Stuff also shows how students can monitor their own comprehension. They can see that many reading difficulties aren‚Äôt the result of not being a ‚Äúgood reader‚Äù‚Äï they simply lack knowledge.
Our students are fortunate to live in an age where so much information is a click away. But to read well‚Äïand think well‚Äïthey need to own that knowledge.

description.standard:
In this podcast, Nina Cnockaert-Guillou talks to Roan Runge about Queerness in Celtic Studies. Roan explains their doctoral research on medieval Irish literature using Queer and Trans theory. They also discuss what it is like to be Queer in the field of medieval Irish studies and Celtic Studies, how students react to Queer readings of medieval Irish literature and what steps we can take to ensure the field is open and welcoming both to people who identify as Queer and/or LGBTQ+, and to Queer readings.¬†



Content warnings:

From 0:45:00 to 0:47:45: transphobia¬†

From 0:59:30 to 1:01:12: transphobic attitudes and politics

description.standard:
What is anti-Semitism? Why is Israel under attack on college campuses?
In this¬†Conversation, released originally in 2014, Bill Kristol spoke with Ruth Wisse, a distinguished professor of Yiddish Literature who taught at Harvard for many years and is one of the world‚Äôs leading experts on anti-Semitism. Wisse explains anti-Semitism as a political phenomenon, which she defines as ‚Äúthe political organization of politics against the Jews.‚Äù She also shares her perspective on anti-Semitism and anti-Israel animus on college campuses, which has intensified since the Hamas attack on Israel on 10/7.¬†

description.standard:
Send us a text - your number will not show, so if you want a response include an email
The literature review presents many challenges. On this episode, Dr. Ellen Beattie walks you through a process that will set you on a path to a successful Chapter 2!
¬†
Ellen is an educational leader, developer, and consultant specializing in positive academic leadership, online teaching and learning, and neuroscience. She also operates an educational consulting platform, the Center for Intentional Learning.
Highlights:
¬†Chapter 2 is an overview of the published literature and discusses the sources in conversation with each other (which requires high-level cognitive skills that can be enhanced by self-care...but the way, how is your self-care?)It often takes longer than other sections because it requires a deep understanding of your field (and this takes TIME) - you are going from a passive consumer to an active creatorThis task requires high-level cognitive skills (how is your self-care?)The literature review is an evolving document - you will be revising and adding to this until your oral defense¬†Think of this task as a puzzle and go through some systematic steps to build your chapter 2Gather your resources (these must be diverse and include multiple viewpoints )Organize your sources (you will want an organizational system for these)Scan your sources and only read¬† the ones relevant to your studyTake notes - you must do this in a systematic way (for example a synthesis matrix - more on that here: https://www.buzzsprout.com/1547113/9643971Mind map or outline to get a picture of how your story is going to be told - this is important - DO NOT SKIP THIS!! Share this with your chair before you write.Review your matrix focusing on synthesis. You must maintain your academic voice - Chapter 2 is not a book report or an annotated bibliography.¬† Think of synthesis as a conversation among the authors of the research you are reading. What are they agreeing about? Disagreeing about?Start writing! Write in whatever order works for you - once you have an outline, follow the outline, but don't force yourself to write from beginning to end in a linear fashion (unless that works for you!)Trust yourself and the process!Seek out and accept feedbackResist rabbit holesStay sane (remember that self-care thing?)Adopt this mantra: Better today than yesterday¬†Connect with Ellen
https://twitter.com/en_beattie
https://www.linkedin.com/in/enbeattie/

Ellen's publication mentioned in intro: The Power of the Positive: Enhancing Online Student Engagement for Adult Literacy Learners, is highlighted in Adult Literacy Education: The International Journal of Literacy, Language, and Numeracy. ¬†

Support this free content: https://www.buzzsprout.com/1547113/supporters/new

Other resources at: http://Expandyourhappy.com

description.standard:
Narrated by Elizabeth Nancett (Cal Poly English, '24)

Full text of the short story: 
https://archive.vcu.edu/english/engweb/webtexts/hour/

Summary of The "Story of an Hour"
The main character learns that her husband has died in a train accident. She demonstrates grief to her surrounding family and friends. However, she secretly pleasures in the idea that she is now a well-off widow, as she remembers having a loveless and passionless marriage that she endured for the sake of having physical and financial stability. However, the husband returns home, as it is revealed that his train was confused with the train that was truly a part of the accident. Unfortunately, the main character dies from the shock of her husband‚Äôs return. 

Themes and Ideas in The Story of an Hour
Femininity and Marriage
Freedom in Relation to Marriage
Expected Roles and Responsibilities of Wives
Female Sexuality, specifically as a Married Woman
Existence, Death, and Loss
Grief and the Etiquette of Grief 
Financially Stability and Its Presence in a Woman‚Äôs Life
Widowhood 

Biography of Kate Chopin (1850-1904)
Catherine ‚ÄúKate‚Äù O‚ÄôFlaherty Chopin was born on February 8, 1850 in St. Louis, Missouri to Thomas O‚ÄôFlaherty and Eliza (n√©e Faris) O‚ÄôFlaherty. Because her mother was of a French background, Chopin became fluent in both English and French, and she later was greatly influenced by French culture, especially in terms of literature. Her first story appeared in papers in 1889, but she privately published her first novel At Fault in 1890. Soon, Chopin began to associate with the St. Louis literary social circle and interacted with the likes of Fredirich Hegel, Emile Zola, and Geroge Sand. Chopin continued to work on her writing and was successful in making profit off of her stories. Short story collections like Bayou Folk (1894), which includes both ‚ÄúThe Story of an Hour‚Äù and ‚ÄúDesiree‚Äôs Baby‚Äù, and A Night in Acadie (1897) were critically-acclaimed, but her best-known work The Awakening (1898) received an on-pouring of disapproval and disgust. It was not until the 1960s that Chopin‚Äôs magnum opus received positive recognition and was not viewed as a lurid tale displaying female sexuality. Unfortunately, Chopin would never witness this success of The Awakening and her many short stories as she died on August 22, 1904. Kate Chopin is now regarded as a classic American author that presents women, their societal value, and their sexuality in a manner propelled the feminist movement to the point it has reached today (see https://www.katechopin.org/biography/)

description.standard:
Join us as we uncover what drove change within the Mormon Church, from government pressure on BYU to admit more black students to the church‚Äôs troubling response. We‚Äôll dive into shocking letters sent to black prospective students, a five-step plan to keep them out, and the protests that followed. Learn how government intervention eventually forced the end of discrimination and explore why Mormon leaders were so uneasy with black students. This episode, featuring historian Dr. Matthew Harris, is part of our series on his book¬†Second Class Saints: Black Mormons and the Struggle for Racial Equality.


We are thrilled to announce that we have reached our donation goal to compensate Dr. Matt Harris for his contributions to this series. We sincerely thank everyone who supported this effort. While the goal to pay Matt has been met, producing this series incurred significant costs for the Open Stories Foundation. description.standard:
Narrated by Julia White (Cal Poly English, '26) 

Full text of the novel: https://ia903104.us.archive.org/34/items/woolf_aroom/woolf_aroom.pdf

About Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) 
Virginia Woolf was Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was an English writer known for her modernist classics and pivotal feminist works. Her writing experiments with prose and often explores dreamstates, nonlinear narratives, and unconventional perspectives. She was truly an innovator on both stylistic and cultural levels. Her most acclaimed works include Mrs. Dalloway, To the Lighthouse, Orlando, and A Room of One‚Äôs Own.

Synopsis 
A Room of One‚Äôs Own follows Woolf's semi-fictional pursuit to research the topic of Women and Fiction. Woolf walks the audience through her own discoveries and frustrations, particularly highlighting the patriarchal hindrances on women to freely create art.

Chapter Guide 
Ch 1. The narrator (a fictionalized Woolf) is asked to speak on the topic of Women and Fiction and attempts to begin her research at the fictional University of Oxbridge, but is met with obstructions on the basis of her sex. She then attends a university luncheon.
Ch 2. (40:51) The narrator begins her research at the British Museum, and finds that although many books are written by men about women, none of the men seem to align on their opinions of them.
Ch 3. (1:11:45) The narrator finds there is little information on the lives of women in history, and constructs an unfortunate tale regarding Shakespeare‚Äôs fictional sister, Judith.
Ch 4. (1:42:07) She goes on to research the lives of prominent female novelists, and asserts that women‚Äôs circumstances and writing styles differ from men entirely, and are
therefore difficult to compare. 
Ch 5. (2:23:16) The narrator studies the fictional Mary Carmichael‚Äôs novel "Life‚Äôs Adventure" and dissects the types of relationships between fictional female characters.
Ch 6. (2:53:32) The narrator stresses the importance of an androgynous mind in creative expression. She ends by reaffirming the need of women to have their own money and own space, and encourages them to write and be heard.

French Translations 
(49:30) ‚ÄúLes femmes sont extr√™mes; elles sont meilleures ou pires que les hommes" : Women are extreme; they are better or worse than men.

Substitutions Made for Date and/or Offensive Language 
(54:19) ‚ÄúPerson‚Äù
(1:29:38) ‚ÄúBlack woman"

description.short: This episode addresses the elephant slouching on its phone in the corner of many literature classrooms. Mary Isbell (University of New Haven) describes her search for a solution to the student reading crisis, incorporating conversations recorded as she
description.standard: This episode addresses the elephant slouching on its phone in the corner of many literature classrooms. Mary Isbell (University of New Haven) describes her search for a solution to the student reading crisis, incorporating conversations recorded as she was writing Searching for Wonder: Teaching Literature with Student-Selected Texts. These conversations reveal the many reasons faculty may be hesitant to set aside their carefully curated reading lists. With her guests, Isbell explores the history of literature instruction, the firm hold of close reading on the teaching of literature, the role of scholarly expertise in the humanities classroom, and the challenge of assessing process in literature courses. Production support by Stefan Sch√∂berlein (Texas A&M University-Central Texas). Transcript available at bit.ly/S0902Transcript. To read the conclusion of Isbell's book Searching For Wonder, visit bit.ly/S09E02Resources.

attributes.name: S09 E02 | How Do We Teach Literature When Students Won‚Äôt Read What We Assign?

description.standard:
Narrated by Julia White (Cal Poly English, '26)

Full text of the novel: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/208/pg208-images.html

About Henry James (1843-1916)
Henry James was an American-British author acclaimed for his critical novels on the differences between his two cultures. He was born in Washington Place, New York and spent much of his childhood in Paris, London, and Geneva. James‚Äôs specialty was prose fiction, yet he found work in journalism as well; he produced 20 novels, 112 tales, and 12 plays. James wrote Daisy Miller in 1879 after settling in London. 

Major Characters 
Frederick Winterbourne: Primary character. Young American man who has spent much of his life in Geneva. 
Daisy Miller: A vacationing young American woman known for her flirtation. 
Mrs. Miller: Daisy‚Äôs subdued mother. 
Randolph Miller: Daisy‚Äôs nine-year-old brother. Prefers America over Europe.  
Mrs. Costello: Winterbourne‚Äôs aunt he stays with in Vevey and Rome. Disapproves of the Miller Family‚Äôs manners. 
Eugenio: The Miller‚Äôs courier.  
Mr. Giovanelli: Daisy‚Äôs Roman courter. 
Mrs. Walker: A friend of Winterbourne and the Miller Family‚Äôs host in Rome.  

Synopsis 
Operating in third-person limited perspective, Daisy Miller is a novel of manners that follows ex-patriot Frederick Winterbourne‚Äôs attraction and curiosity of Daisy Miller, a coquette (woman who trifles with men‚Äôs affections) American girl scolded for her behavior in urbane European society. 

Chapter Guide 
Ch 1. Winterbourne and Daisy meet in Vivey. He finds her beautiful and flirtatious. The two make plans to spend a day at the Castle of Chillon.  
Ch 2. (24:03) Winterbourne finds Mrs. Costello does not approve of the Miller family. Winterbourne speaks in the garden of their hotel to Daisy and Mrs. Miller and attempts to 	go on a late-night boat ride with Daisy. The pair later go to the Castle of Chillon by boat on an afternoon tour. Daisy asks Winterbourne to meet her in Rome in winter.
Ch 3. (56:00) Winter. David meets Mrs. Costello in Rome, and she informs him she remains in disapproval of the Miller family. He goes to meet a friend, Mrs. Walker, and 		runs into the Millers. He accompanies Daisy on a stroll with Mr. Giovanelli.
Ch 4. (1:26) Winterbourne sees Daisy and Mr. Giovanelli at Mrs. Walker‚Äôs party, then on a stroll, and finally at the Colosseum. 

French Translations 
(27:57:00) ‚ÄúTout bonnement!‚Äù : Quite simply! 
(1:28:30) ‚ÄúElle s‚Äôaffiche‚Äù : It‚Äôs on display. 
(1:41:25) ‚Äú...and thinks Miss Miller a young lady qui se passe ses fantaisies!‚Äù : and thinks Miss Miller a young lady who indulges her fantasies. 
(1:43:48) ‚Äú...a young lady du meilleur monde‚Äù : a young lady of the best world.

description.standard:
Listen to this audiobook in full for free onhttps://hotaudiobook.com/free Title: To Read Stuff You Have to Know Stuff: Helping Students Build and Use Prior Knowledge¬†Author: Kelly GallagherNarrator: Kelly GallagherFormat: UnabridgedLength: 6:02:14Language: EnglishRelease date: 07-08-2025Publisher: Blackstone AudiobooksGenres: Non-Fiction, EducationSummary:In the age of click-and-go reading, why do students need to know information when they can just look things up?
Bestselling author Kelly Gallagher argues that to think critically, it‚Äôs imperative that we teach kids stuff. Lots of it. Why? Because students who know more are able to read more, and read better.
In To Read Stuff You Have to Know Stuff, Kelly draws from his own teaching practice to share the importance of building students‚Äô prior knowledge at four levels:
Words: How building knowledge helps students to overcome word poverty
Sentences and Passages: How building knowledge helps students to comprehend ‚Äúsmall‚Äù reading
Articles: How building knowledge helps students to critically read articles‚Äïan important skill in our digital age
Books: How building knowledge moves students away from fake reading and back into reading full-length books 
To Read Stuff You Have to Know Stuff also shows how students can monitor their own comprehension. They can see that many reading difficulties aren‚Äôt the result of not being a ‚Äúgood reader‚Äù‚Äï they simply lack knowledge.
Our students are fortunate to live in an age where so much information is a click away. But to read well‚Äïand think well‚Äïthey need to own that knowledge.

description.short: In this podcast, Nina Cnockaert-Guillou talks to Roan Runge about Queerness in Celtic Studies. Roan explains their doctoral research on medieval Irish literature using Queer and Trans theory. They also discuss what it is like to be Queer in the field of
description.standard:
In this podcast, Nina Cnockaert-Guillou talks to Roan Runge about Queerness in Celtic Studies. Roan explains their doctoral research on medieval Irish literature using Queer and Trans theory. They also discuss what it is like to be Queer in the field of medieval Irish studies and Celtic Studies, how students react to Queer readings of medieval Irish literature and what steps we can take to ensure the field is open and welcoming both to people who identify as Queer and/or LGBTQ+, and to Queer readings.¬†



Content warnings:

From 0:45:00 to 0:47:45: transphobia¬†

From 0:59:30 to 1:01:12: transphobic attitudes and politics

description.standard:
What is anti-Semitism? Why is Israel under attack on college campuses?
In this¬†Conversation, released originally in 2014, Bill Kristol spoke with Ruth Wisse, a distinguished professor of Yiddish Literature who taught at Harvard for many years and is one of the world‚Äôs leading experts on anti-Semitism. Wisse explains anti-Semitism as a political phenomenon, which she defines as ‚Äúthe political organization of politics against the Jews.‚Äù She also shares her perspective on anti-Semitism and anti-Israel animus on college campuses, which has intensified since the Hamas attack on Israel on 10/7.¬†

Send us a text - your number will not show, so if you want a response include an email
The literature review presents many challenges. On this episode, Dr. Ellen Beattie walks you through a process that will set you on a path to a successful Chapter 2!
¬†
Ellen is an educational leader, developer, and consultant specializing in positive academic leadership, online teaching and learning, and neuroscience. She also operates an educational consulting platform, the Center for Intentional Learning.
Highlights:
¬†Chapter 2 is an overview of the published literature and discusses the sources in conversation with each other (which requires high-level cognitive skills that can be enhanced by self-care...but the way, how is your self-care?)It often takes longer than other sections because it requires a deep understanding of your field (and this takes TIME) - you are going from a passive consumer to an active creatorThis task requires high-level cognitive skills (how is your self-care?)The literature review is an evolving document - you will be revising and adding to this until your oral defense¬†Think of this task as a puzzle and go through some systematic steps to build your chapter 2Gather your resources (these must be diverse and include multiple viewpoints )Organize your sources (you will want an organizational system for these)Scan your sources and only read¬† the ones relevant to your studyTake notes - you must do this in a systematic way (for example a synthesis matrix - more on that here: https://www.buzzsprout.com/1547113/9643971Mind map or outline to get a picture of how your story is going to be told - this is important - DO NOT SKIP THIS!! Share this with your chair before you write.Review your matrix focusing on synthesis. You must maintain your academic voice - Chapter 2 is not a book report or an annotated bibliography.¬† Think of synthesis as a conversation among the authors of the research you are reading. What are they agreeing about? Disagreeing about?Start writing! Write in whatever order works for you - once you have an outline, follow the outline, but don't force yourself to write from beginning to end in a linear fashion (unless that works for you!)Trust yourself and the process!Seek out and accept feedbackResist rabbit holesStay sane (remember that self-care thing?)Adopt this mantra: Better today than yesterday¬†Connect with Ellen
https://twitter.com/en_beattie
https://www.linkedin.com/in/enbeattie/

Ellen's publication mentioned in intro: The Power of the Positive: Enhancing Online Student Engagement for Adult Literacy Learners, is highlighted in Adult Literacy Education: The International Journal of Literacy, Language, and Numeracy. ¬†

description.standard:
Narrated by Elizabeth Nancett (Cal Poly English, '24)

Full text of the short story: 
https://archive.vcu.edu/english/engweb/webtexts/hour/

Summary of The "Story of an Hour"
The main character learns that her husband has died in a train accident. She demonstrates grief to her surrounding family and friends. However, she secretly pleasures in the idea that she is now a well-off widow, as she remembers having a loveless and passionless marriage that she endured for the sake of having physical and financial stability. However, the husband returns home, as it is revealed that his train was confused with the train that was truly a part of the accident. Unfortunately, the main character dies from the shock of her husband‚Äôs return. 

Themes and Ideas in The Story of an Hour
Femininity and Marriage
Freedom in Relation to Marriage
Expected Roles and Responsibilities of Wives
Female Sexuality, specifically as a Married Woman
Existence, Death, and Loss
Grief and the Etiquette of Grief 
Financially Stability and Its Presence in a Woman‚Äôs Life
Widowhood 

Biography of Kate Chopin (1850-1904)
Catherine ‚ÄúKate‚Äù O‚ÄôFlaherty Chopin was born on February 8, 1850 in St. Louis, Missouri to Thomas O‚ÄôFlaherty and Eliza (n√©e Faris) O‚ÄôFlaherty. Because her mother was of a French background, Chopin became fluent in both English and French, and she later was greatly influenced by French culture, especially in terms of literature. Her first story appeared in papers in 1889, but she privately published her first novel At Fault in 1890. Soon, Chopin began to associate with the St. Louis literary social circle and interacted with the likes of Fredirich Hegel, Emile Zola, and Geroge Sand. Chopin continued to work on her writing and was successful in making profit off of her stories. Short story collections like Bayou Folk (1894), which includes both ‚ÄúThe Story of an Hour‚Äù and ‚ÄúDesiree‚Äôs Baby‚Äù, and A Night in Acadie (1897) were critically-acclaimed, but her best-known work The Awakening (1898) received an on-pouring of disapproval and disgust. It was not until the 1960s that Chopin‚Äôs magnum opus received positive recognition and was not viewed as a lurid tale displaying female sexuality. Unfortunately, Chopin would never witness this success of The Awakening and her many short stories as she died on August 22, 1904. Kate Chopin is now regarded as a classic American author that presents women, their societal value, and their sexuality in a manner propelled the feminist movement to the point it has reached today (see https://www.katechopin.org/biography/)

description.standard:
Talking Literature presents free audio and text material designed to make literature more accessible for everyone. Each episode of the podcast features important literary texts that are often included in literary surveys and seminars. 

Season 1 features podcasts created during the 23-24 Academic Year and includes works by James Joyce, Kate Chopin, and Henry James.

This podcast reflects Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo's Learn by Doing approach to education and undergraduate research. It began as a Cal Poly English senior project. This podcast has been generously supported by a 2024 Cal Poly College of Liberal Arts Summer Undergraduate Research Program Grant. The inspiration for this podcast was the Library of Congress‚Äô program ‚ÄúTalking Books and Reading Disabilities" (https://www.loc.gov/nls/services-and-resources/informational-publications/talking-books-reading-disabilities/).
